subject: Re: [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
msgSnippet: Dear rxqch (hope i spelled your name correct) [quoting JTest 4.5 help]: To have Jtest suppress errors for inputs that you do not expect to occur, use the @pre
messageBody:
Dear rxqch (hope i spelled your name correct)

[quoting JTest 4.5 help]:
To have Jtest suppress errors for inputs that you do not expect to
occur, use the @pre tag to specify what range of inputs is
permissible.

For example, if negative inputs are not allowed, you would enter the
following comment above the appropriate method:
/** @pre arg >=0 */
[end quote]

So using the '@pre' parasoft tag does not warn the developer, quite
contrary:
in the example quoted the parameter 'arg' is not expected to be
negative. When it does have a negative value, JTest will suppress
errors.

Final question for rxqch:
You as a Parasoft techie should be able to determine the number of
runtime exceptions present in JTest version 4.5, shouldn't you ?
Why don't you enlighten us, or did you add tons of 'suppression' tags
?

A simple extrapolation would indicate
junit.jar, 120 Kb = 24 runtime exceptions
ant.jar, 415 Kb = 255
jtest.zip, 252 --> 160 ?
jtest gui.zip, 3.148 Kb --> 1500 ?

yours sincerely
Arie Roy


--- In junit@y..., "rxqch" <rxqch@y...> wrote:
> Hi, I work with parasoft tech support and the answer to the
question
> below is yes. One can use an @pre tag in javadoc to find such
> problems.
>
> Carson
>
> --- In junit@y..., Ilja Preu√ü <ilja.preuss@w...> wrote:
> > > The problem is that I don't know if there was a problem with
> > > the input, the processing or something random. If your code
> > > returns an IllegalArgumentException, then I have a much
> > > better idea of the issues.
> >
> > If you are on the same team, you could ask him. Possibly you
could
> even
> > find out by simply looking at the code and/or the JUnit tests.
> >
> > One point I find more critical is that invalid input should be
> > fail-fast. If a method fails because you provided invalid input
to a
> > prior method call, such problems are really hard to find. Can
JTest
> help
> > with such issues?
> >
> > Regards, Ilja
